etymology.description: 糖 (sugar) + 葫芦 (gourd) = ‘sugar(-coated) gourd’ → a sugar-coated skewer resembling a gourd.
etymology.interpretation: Literally ‘sugar gourd’, naming a skewer of fruit—traditionally hawthorn—coated in hard sugar syrup so it looks gourd-like. Widely known as a classic northern Chinese street snack.
etymology.simplification: 葫蘆 → 葫芦 by simplifying 蘆 to 芦 in the grass-radical series to reduce strokes; 糖 unchanged.

examples.chinese: 我最爱冬天买糖葫芦(我最愛冬天買糖葫蘆)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zuì ài dōngtiān mǎi táng húlu.
examples.english: I love buying candied hawthorns in winter.

examples.chinese: 这家店的冰糖葫芦很脆(這家店的冰糖葫蘆很脆)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiā diàn de bīngtáng húlu hěn cuì.
examples.english: The bingtanghulu here is very crunchy.

examples.chinese: 他把山楂串好再裹上糖浆做成糖葫芦(他把山楂串好再裹上糖漿做成糖葫蘆)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bǎ shānzhā chuàn hǎo zài guǒ shàng tángjiāng zuò chéng táng húlu.
examples.english: He skewers the hawthorns, coats them with syrup, and makes tanghulu.
